title: Leaving Certificate Examination 2025 Mathematics Foundation Level

questions.text:
(a) Complete the stem and leaf diagram below to show the information in the table. 

|  13 | 15 | 17 | 18 | 21 | 23 | 26  |
|  29 | 29 | 30 | 34 | 36 | 44 | 46  |

|  1 | 3 |  |  |  |   |
|  2 |  |  |  |  |   |
|  3 |  |  |  |  |   |
|  4 |  |  |  |  |   |

Key: 1|3 means 13 years of age
(b) Find the range of the ages of the people in the group.
(c) Find the mode of the ages of the people in the group.
(d) Find the mean age of the five oldest people (30, 34, 36, 44, 46) in the group.
(a) (i) A group, going on a camping holiday, buy 3 of the 500 gram boxes. Find the total weight of these boxes, in grams.
(a) (ii) They also buy a number of the 750 gram boxes. In total, the group buy 4500 grams of the cereal. Find how many of the 750 gram boxes they bought.
(b) John and Mary divide €300 between them in the ratio 5:7. Mary gets the larger amount. Find how much money Mary gets.
(c) Tom, Jack, and Michael went shopping and spent a total of €200. Jack spent €3 more than Tom. Michael spent €8 more than Tom. Find how much each of them spent.

(a) (i) Give one example of a ‘lunch special’ that a customer could choose from the menu below. 

|  Starter | Main Course | Dessert  |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  Soup | Roast Chicken | Apple Crumble  |
|  Salad | Grilled Fish | Ice Cream  |
|   | Steak | Chocolate Cake  |
|   | Vegetarian Salad |   |
(a) (ii) How many different choices of ‘lunch special’ are available?
(a) (iii) A particular customer does not choose soup nor chocolate cake. How many different choices of ‘lunch special’ are available to that customer if they still choose three courses?

(b) (i) Complete the table below by filling in the 2 missing values. 

|   | Walking | Running | Cycling | Total  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  Male | 8 | 5 | 10 |   |
|  Female | 4 |  | 8 | 19  |
(b) (ii) A person is chosen at random from the group of 42 in the table above. What is the probability that the person chosen is a female?
(a) Find the value of $A$, the number of electricity units used, given the meter readings: Present = 80,877 and Previous = 80,455.
(b) Find the value of $B$, the standing charge for this 58 day period, where the standing charge is €0.7614 per day. Give your answer in euro, correct to 2 decimal places.
(c) The electricity units cost €167.53 and there is also a PSO levy of €6.46. Find the value of $C$, the total excluding VAT. Give your answer in euro, correct to 2 decimal places.
(d) VAT is charged at 9% on the total. Find the value of $D$, how much VAT Mary must pay. Give your answer in euro, correct to 2 decimal places.
(e) Find the value of $E$, the total including VAT. Give your answer in euro, correct to 2 decimal places.
(a) The exchange rate at the time of her trip was €1 = £0.88 sterling. Jackie changed €400 spending money into pounds sterling before she travelled. How much sterling did she get?
(b) (i) Find the total (in pounds sterling) of the other costs associated with Jackie’s trip: Flights - £150, Accommodation - £110, Match ticket - £60, Train fare - £45.
(b) (ii) Find the total of these other costs in euro. Use the exchange rate €1 = £0.88 sterling. Give your answer correct to the nearest euro.

(c) Jackie’s home in Ireland is 20 km from the airport. Her hotel in England is 15 miles from the stadium. Which of these is the shorter distance? Use the fact that 5 miles is approximately the same distance as 8 km. Show the calculations you made to come to your answer.
(a) (i) The diagram below shows a square tile with a pattern made up of two right-angled triangles and a parallelogram. What is the size of the angle marked A on the diagram?
(a) (ii) Find the length marked $x$ and the length marked $y$ on the diagram.
(a) (iii) Lily uses 14 of these tiles to tile the floor of her bathroom. Find the total area of 14 of these tiles. Give your answer in $\mathrm{cm}^2$.

(b) The diagram below shows the location of two towns, $X$ and $Y$. The scale on the diagram is $1\mathrm{cm} = 10\mathrm{km}$. Each small square on the grid has sides of length 1 cm. The circle shows the region that is within $30\mathrm{km}$ of Town $X$. A supermarket is to be built between the two towns such that it will be within $30 \mathrm{km}$ of town $X$ and also within $50 \mathrm{km}$ of town $Y$. Draw a suitable circle of radius 5 cm on the diagram below and shade the region on the diagram where the supermarket could be built.
(a) Draw pattern 4 of the sequence in the grid below, given the first 3 patterns in the sequence of patterns of dots.

(b) Complete the table below showing the number of dots in some of the patterns in the sequence. 

|   | Number of Dots  |
| --- | --- |
|  Pattern 1 | 4  |
|  Pattern 2 | 7  |
|  Pattern 3 |   |
|  Pattern 4 |   |
|  Pattern 5 |   |
|  Pattern 6 |   |
(c) The number of dots in pattern $k$ of the sequence can be found using the formula: Number of dots = $3k + 1$. How many dots are in pattern 42 of the sequence?
(d) Pattern $m$ in the sequence has 154 dots. Find the value of $m$.
(a) Write down the co-ordinates of the point $E$ in the diagram showing triangles $ABC$ and $BDE$, where $A = (2, 1)$, $B = (4, 1)$, and $C = (2, 3).
(b) (i) Write down the lengths of $[AB]$ and $[BD]$ from the diagram.
(b) (ii) Use your answers to part (b)(i) to work out the value of $k$, the scale factor of the enlargement transforming triangle $ABC$ to triangle $BDE$.
(c) The area of the triangle $ABC$ is 2 square units. Using this, or otherwise, find the area of the triangle $BDE$.
(d) Use the Theorem of Pythagoras, or otherwise, to find the distance from $B$ to $C$. That is, find $|BC|$. Give your answer correct to 1 decimal place.
(a) (i) What time did Aoife start her journey based on the distance-time graph?
(a) (ii) What do you think might have happened during the part of her journey labelled A on the distance-time graph?
(a) (iii) How long did Aoife stay with her friend based on the distance-time graph?
(a) (iv) Find the total distance travelled by Aoife, in km, based on the distance-time graph.
(a) (v) Find Aoife’s average speed, in km/hour, on the journey home. Give your answer correct to the nearest whole number.

(b) (i) On the grid below, draw a bar chart to represent the information in the table showing the number of people flying to different countries. 

|  Destination | Greece | France | Portugal | Spain  |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  Number of People | 10 | 35 | 30 | 45  |
(b) (ii) Find the percentage of the 120 people surveyed who were flying to Spain.
(b) (iii) Use the pie chart to work out the number of people who were flying to Portugal in the second survey.
(a) The solar panels are rectangular in shape. They are 98 cm wide and 172 cm long. Find the area of one solar panel, in cm².

(b) (i) Assume that, on average, one of these solar panels will produce 0.4 units of electricity per hour for 5 hours each day. Find the number of units of electricity that this solar panel will produce on average per day.
(b) (ii) Find the number of units of electricity that 4 of these solar panels will produce in one year (365 days).

(b) (iii) Amanda will use 95% of the units of electricity that 4 solar panels produce. She is currently paying €0.3970 for each unit of electricity she uses. Using your answer from part b(ii), find how much she will save in 1 year because of the panels. Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.
(c) (i) Convert 1.5 m and 0.8 m to cm for the dimensions of the table top.
(c) (ii) Find the volume of concrete needed to make the rectangular table top that is 1.5 m long, 0.8 m wide, and 14 cm high. Give your answer in cm³.
(c) (iii) Each cylindrical column has a radius of 10 cm and a height of 90 cm. Find the volume of concrete needed to make the 2 columns. Give your answer correct to the nearest cm³.
(c) (iv) The total volume of concrete needed to make the table is 225 litres. A litre of concrete weighs 2.24 kg. Find the total weight of the table, in kg.
(a) (i) In Week 1, Jacinta works 30 hours at €11.30 per hour. Find Jacinta’s gross pay for Week 1.
(a) (ii) In Week 2, Jacinta works 38 hours. She is paid €11.30 per hour for the first 30 hours and €16.95 for every extra hour. Find Jacinta’s gross pay for Week 2.
(a) (iii) In Week 3, Jacinta’s gross pay is €525.45. Find how many extra hours Jacinta worked in Week 3 compared to Week 1.
(b) (i) In Week 4, Jacinta’s gross pay is €508.50. She pays tax at a rate of 20% on her gross pay. Find Jacinta’s gross tax for Week 4.
(b) (ii) Jacinta’s weekly tax credit for Week 4 is €76.92. Find Jacinta’s net pay for Week 4.
(c) (i) Jacinta drives for 222 km. Her car uses 1 litre of petrol for every 18.5 km that it travels. Find the number of litres of petrol used on her drive.
(c) (ii) The petrol used on this journey costs €1.73 per litre. Find the cost of the petrol used on her drive.
(d) The value of Jacinta's car decreases (depreciates) by 10% each year. She paid €23,000 for her car exactly 2 years ago. Find the value of the car today.
